section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: UDP firewall traversal
Problem Statement
section.t: Today UDP is often blocked (“99% of UDP is garbage”) but volume of (good) UDP traffic grows, e.g. RTCWEB uses UDP for data and media. Hard to establish session/flow state at firewalls as block rules are stateless. Therefore we need an explicit contract to establish state along the path (as today’s implicit contract does with TCP).

section.title: Information Exposure
section.t: Use of identifiers (“tubes”) beyond the five-tuple to link packets together; Explicit ignaling/negotiation of tube start/end: Indicate start/stop to middlebox and confirm connection establishment by receiver.

section.section: [Describe what a firewall would do with this information.]

section.title: Information Exposure
section.t: e.g. explicit indication of data rate for CBR traffic: video traffic could provide maximum rate with current encoding; network could expose rate shaping to simplify probing; endhost/network could provide indication of sudden changes in bandwidth demand/offer

section.title: Information Exposure
section.t: explicit indication of loss- vs. latency-sensitive traffic: loss-sensitive traffic faces larger buffer delay,but lower loss rate (tradeoff)

section.title: Mechanism
section.t: latency-sensitive traffic could be managed in a different queue or with use of AQM such as PIE/ CoDel, but might see higher loss rates (no prioritization)
provider decides about bandwidth sharing between both services, and might or might not expose this information

section.title: Information Exposure
section.t: Explicit indication of relative flow priority, relative packet priority within a flow

section.title: Mechanism
section.t: e.g. if service has multiple simultaneous transmission of video/audio/control data, interactive data would be prioritized within same service
e.g. more important packets such as I-frames in video could be prioritized within same flow/tube
